Abstract

We prove Helly-type theorems for line transversals to disjoint unit balls in ℝdsuperscriptℝ𝑑\mathbb{R}^{d}blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. In particular, we show that a family of n⩾2⁢d𝑛2𝑑n\geqslant 2ditalic_n ⩾ 2 italic_d disjoint unit balls in ℝdsuperscriptℝ𝑑\mathbb{R}^{d}blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT has a line transversal if, for some ordering ≺precedes\prec≺ of the balls, any subfamily of 2⁢d2𝑑2d2 italic_d balls admits a line transversal consistent with ≺precedes\prec≺. We also prove that a family of n⩾4⁢d−1𝑛4𝑑1n\geqslant 4d-1italic_n ⩾ 4 italic_d - 1 disjoint unit balls in ℝdsuperscriptℝ𝑑\mathbb{R}^{d}blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT admits a line transversal if any subfamily of size 4⁢d−14𝑑14d-14 italic_d - 1 admits a transversal.

1 Introduction

Helly’s celebrated theorem, published in 1923, states that a finite family of convex sets in ℝdsuperscriptℝ𝑑\mathbb{R}^{d}blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT has non-empty intersection if and only if any subfamily of size at most d+1𝑑1d+1italic_d + 1 has non-empty intersection. Subsequent results of similar flavor (that is, if every subset of size k𝑘kitalic_k of a set 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S}caligraphic_S has property 𝒫𝒫\cal Pcaligraphic_P then 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S}caligraphic_S has property 𝒫𝒫\cal Pcaligraphic_P) have been called Helly-type theorems and the minimal such k𝑘kitalic_k is known as the associated Helly number. Helly-type theorems and tight bounds on Helly numbers have been the object of active research in combinatorial geometry. In this paper, we investigate Helly-type theorems for the existence of line transversals to a family of objects, i.e. lines that intersect every member of the family.

History.

The earliest Helly-type theorems in geometric transversal theory appeared about five decades ago. In 1957, Hadwiger [12] showed that an ordered family 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S}caligraphic_S of compact convex sets in the plane admits a line transversal if every triple admits a line transversal compatible with the ordering. (Note that a line transversal to 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S}caligraphic_S may not respect the ordering on 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S}caligraphic_S; to prove the existence of a line transversal that respects the ordering on 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S}caligraphic_S one needs the assumption that any four-tuple admits an order-respecting line transversal.) In what follows, we shall talk about a Hadwiger-type theorem when the family of objects under consideration is ordered.

The same year, Danzer [5] proved the following result concerning families of pairwise disjoint unit discs in the plane: if such a family consists of at least 5 discs, and if any 5 of these discs are met by some line, then there exists a line meeting all the discs of the family. This answered a question of Hadwiger [11], who gave an example (5 circles, almost touching and with centers forming a regular pentagon) which shows that 5 cannot be replaced by 4. Grünbaum [8] showed that the same result holds if “unit disc” is replaced by “unit square”, and conjectured that the result holds for families of disjoint translates of any compact convex set in the plane. This long-standing conjecture was finally proved by Tverberg [19]. A weaker form of the conjecture which assumed 128 instead of 5 had been established earlier by Katchalski [16].

Danzer [5] conjectured that Helly-type theorems exist for line transversals to disjoint unit balls in arbitrary dimension. The first positive result was obtained by Hadwiger [10] for the case of families of “thinly distributed” balls, where the distance between any two balls is at least the sum of their radii. This result was extended by Ambrus et al. [1] to disjoint unit balls, in arbitrary dimension, the centers of which are at distance at least 2⁢2+22222\sqrt{2+\sqrt{2}}2 square-root start_ARG 2 + square-root start_ARG 2 end_ARG end_ARG. Danzer’s conjecture for three-dimensional disjoint unit balls, without additional assumption on their distribution, was only settled in 2001 by Holmsen et al. [14]. It should be stressed that in dimension three (and higher), neither Hadwiger nor Helly-type theorems exist for line transversals to general convex objects, not even for translates of a convex compact set [15].

In his paper [5], Danzer also asked whether the Helly number for line transversals to disjoint unit balls in ℝdsuperscriptℝ𝑑\mathbb{R}^{d}blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is a strictly increasing function of d𝑑ditalic_d. The only known lower bound is the planar example of Hadwiger [11]. This number was proved to be at most d2superscript𝑑2d^{2}italic_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT for thinly distributed balls in ℝdsuperscriptℝ𝑑\mathbb{R}^{d}blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT by Hadwiger [10], a bound improved to 2⁢d−12𝑑12d-12 italic_d - 1 by Grünbaum [9] using the topological Helly theorem. For disjoint unit balls in dimension three, Holmsen et al. [14] proved bounds of respectively 12121212 and 46464646 for the Hadwiger-type and Helly-type theorems, which were later improved to 12121212 and 18181818 by Cheong et al. [4].

We refer the reader to the recent survey by Wenger [20] for a broader discussion of geometric transversal theory.

Our results.

In this paper we complete the proof of Danzer’s conjecture. More precisely, we show that Helly-type theorems exist for line transversals to families of pairwise-inflatable balls in ℝdsuperscriptℝ𝑑\mathbb{R}^{d}blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. A family ℱℱ\mathcal{F}caligraphic_F of balls in ℝdsuperscriptℝ𝑑\mathbb{R}^{d}blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is called pairwise-inflatable if for every pair of balls B1,B2∈ℱsubscript𝐵1subscript𝐵2ℱB_{1},B_{2}\in\mathcal{F}italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ caligraphic_F we have γ2>2⁢(r12+r22)superscript𝛾22superscriptsubscript𝑟12superscriptsubscript𝑟22\gamma^{2}>2(r_{1}^{2}+r_{2}^{2})italic_γ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT > 2 ( italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ), where risubscript𝑟𝑖r_{i}italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the radius of Bisubscript𝐵𝑖B_{i}italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ is the distance between their centers. A family of disjoint unit balls is pairwise-inflatable, since γ2>2⁢(r12+r22)superscript𝛾22superscriptsubscript𝑟12superscriptsubscript𝑟22\gamma^{2}>2(r_{1}^{2}+r_{2}^{2})italic_γ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT > 2 ( italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) implies γ>r1+r2𝛾subscript𝑟1subscript𝑟2\gamma>r_{1}+r_{2}italic_γ > italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT when r1=r2subscript𝑟1subscript𝑟2r_{1}=r_{2}italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and so is a family of balls that is “thinly distributed” in Hadwiger’s sense. Pairwise-inflatable families of balls are not only more general than families of disjoint congruent balls but allow to generalize most of our proofs obtained in three or four dimensions to arbitrary dimension; the key property, which we prove in this paper, is that the set of pairwise-inflatable families is closed under intersection with affine subspaces, unlike the set of families of disjoint congruent balls.

An order-respecting line transversal to a subset of an ordered family is a line transversal that respects the order induced by the family on that subset. An ordered family ℱℱ\mathcal{F}caligraphic_F of pairwise-inflatable balls is said to have property (O⁢R)⁢T𝑂𝑅𝑇(OR)T( italic_O italic_R ) italic_T if it admits a (order-respecting) line transversal. If every k𝑘kitalic_k or fewer members of ℱℱ\mathcal{F}caligraphic_F admit a (order-respecting) line transversal then ℱℱ\mathcal{F}caligraphic_F is said to have property (O⁢R)⁢T⁢(k)𝑂𝑅𝑇𝑘(OR)T(k)( italic_O italic_R ) italic_T ( italic_k ). Our first main result requires that the line transversals to the subfamilies induce consistent orderings:

Theorem 1.

For any ordered family of pairwise-inflatable balls in ℝdsuperscriptℝ𝑑\mathbb{R}^{d}blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, O⁢R⁢T⁢(2⁢d)𝑂𝑅𝑇2𝑑ORT(2d)italic_O italic_R italic_T ( 2 italic_d ) implies T𝑇Titalic_T and O⁢R⁢T⁢(2⁢d+1)𝑂𝑅𝑇2𝑑1ORT(2d+1)italic_O italic_R italic_T ( 2 italic_d + 1 ) implies O⁢R⁢T𝑂𝑅𝑇ORTitalic_O italic_R italic_T.

We then remove the condition on the ordering at the cost of increasing the Helly number to 4⁢d−14𝑑14d-14 italic_d - 1 and restricting ourselves to disjoint unit balls:

Theorem 2.

For any family of disjoint unit balls in ℝdsuperscriptℝ𝑑\mathbb{R}^{d}blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, T⁢(4⁢d−1)𝑇4𝑑1T(4d-1)italic_T ( 4 italic_d - 1 ) implies T𝑇Titalic_T.

Our results are thus both qualitative and quantitative: we generalize Danzer’s result to arbitrary dimension and prove that the Helly number grows at most linearly with the dimension. We build on the work of Holmsen et al. [14] who obtained results similar to Theorems 1 and 2 for disjoint unit balls in three dimensions, albeit with larger bounds on Helly numbers (12121212 and 46464646 instead of 6666 and 11111111, respectively). A previous version of this paper, also restricted to disjoint unit balls in three dimensions, appeared in the Symposium on Computational Geometry 2005 [3].

Paper outline.

To prove Theorem 1, we start with a family of balls having property O⁢R⁢T⁢(2⁢d)𝑂𝑅𝑇2𝑑ORT(2d)italic_O italic_R italic_T ( 2 italic_d ) and continuously shrink them until that property no longer holds, following Hadwiger’s approach [12]. Before the set of order-respecting line transversals to a 2⁢d2𝑑2d2 italic_d-tuple of balls disappears, it first reduces to a single line (Corollary 12) and this line is an isolated line transversal to 2⁢d−12𝑑12d-12 italic_d - 1 of the balls (Proposition 13). That line has then to be a line transversal to the whole family and Theorem 1 follows; considerations on geometric permutations yield Theorem 2.

Proving the two properties mentioned above (Corollary 12 and Proposition 13) is elementary in the plane but requires considerably more work in higher dimension. Our proofs rely on Proposition 4, the cornerstone of this paper, which shows that the directions of order-respecting line transversals to a family of pairwise-inflatable balls form a strictly convex subset of 𝕊d−1superscript𝕊𝑑1\mathbb{S}^{d-1}blackboard_S start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. This directly implies Corollary 12 and yields that order-respecting line transversals form a contractible set in line space. From there, a well-known topological analogue of Helly’s theorem (Theorem 3) leads to a weaker version of Theorem 1 sufficient to prove Proposition 13.

2 Preliminaries

Transversals.

Let ℱℱ\mathcal{F}caligraphic_F be a finite family of disjoint compact convex sets ℱℱ\mathcal{F}caligraphic_F in ℝdsuperscriptℝ𝑑\mathbb{R}^{d}blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT with a given linear order ≺ℱsubscriptprecedesℱ\prec_{\mathcal{F}}≺ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_F end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. We will call ℱℱ\mathcal{F}caligraphic_F a sequence to stress the existence of this order. A line transversal to a sequence ℱℱ\mathcal{F}caligraphic_F is an oriented line that intersects all the objects of ℱℱ\mathcal{F}caligraphic_F in the order prescribed by ≺ℱsubscriptprecedesℱ\prec_{\mathcal{F}}≺ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_F end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. A line transversal is strict if it intersects the interior of each object in ℱℱ\mathcal{F}caligraphic_F.

For a sequence ℱℱ\mathcal{F}caligraphic_F, let 𝒦⁢(ℱ)⊂𝕊d−1𝒦ℱsuperscript𝕊𝑑1\mathcal{K}(\mathcal{F})\subset\mathbb{S}^{d-1}caligraphic_K ( caligraphic_F ) ⊂ blackboard_S start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT denote the set of directions of line transversals to ℱℱ\mathcal{F}caligraphic_F. That is, a direction vector v∈𝕊d−1𝑣superscript𝕊𝑑1v\in\mathbb{S}^{d-1}italic_v ∈ blackboard_S start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is in 𝒦⁢(ℱ)𝒦ℱ\mathcal{K}(\mathcal{F})caligraphic_K ( caligraphic_F ) if there is a line transversal to ℱℱ\mathcal{F}caligraphic_F with direction v𝑣vitalic_v. Note that the direction vector of a line transversal determines the order in which it intersects a family of disjoint convex objects. Thus, if sequences ℱ1subscriptℱ1\mathcal{F}_{1}caligraphic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and ℱ2subscriptℱ2\mathcal{F}_{2}caligraphic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are two distinct orderings of the same collection of objects, then 𝒦⁢(ℱ1)𝒦subscriptℱ1\mathcal{K}(\mathcal{F}_{1})caligraphic_K ( caligraphic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) and 𝒦⁢(ℱ2)𝒦subscriptℱ2\mathcal{K}(\mathcal{F}_{2})caligraphic_K ( caligraphic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) are disjoint. We will call 𝒦⁢(ℱ)𝒦ℱ\mathcal{K}(\mathcal{F})caligraphic_K ( caligraphic_F ) the cone of directions of ℱℱ\mathcal{F}caligraphic_F. Similarly, let 𝒦∘⁢(ℱ)superscript𝒦ℱ\mathcal{K}^{\circ}(\mathcal{F})caligraphic_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∘ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( caligraphic_F ) be the set of directions of strict line transversals to ℱℱ\mathcal{F}caligraphic_F.

Note that all our line transversals must respect a given order. Only in Section 5 will we consider line transversals without order restriction. For clarity, let us call such a line transversal an unordered line transversal.

We consider the natural topology over the set of oriented lines in ℝdsuperscriptℝ𝑑\mathbb{R}^{d}blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT: U𝑈Uitalic_U is a neighborhood of a line ℓℓ\ellroman_ℓ if and only if for some δ>0𝛿0\delta>0italic_δ > 0 it contains all lines ℓ′superscriptℓ′\ell^{\prime}roman_ℓ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT such that the shortest distance between ℓℓ\ellroman_ℓ and ℓ′superscriptℓ′\ell^{\prime}roman_ℓ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and the angle between their direction vectors are both less than δ𝛿\deltaitalic_δ. An isolated line transversal to a family of objects ℱℱ\mathcal{F}caligraphic_F is an isolated point of the set of line transversals to ℱℱ\mathcal{F}caligraphic_F, that is, a line transversal ℓℓ\ellroman_ℓ which is a connected component of the line transversals to ℱℱ\mathcal{F}caligraphic_F.

Given a ball A𝐴Aitalic_A and a direction v𝑣vitalic_v in ℝdsuperscriptℝ𝑑\mathbb{R}^{d}blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, we denote by Pv⁢(A)subscript𝑃𝑣𝐴P_{v}(A)italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_A ) the (d−1)𝑑1(d-1)( italic_d - 1 )-dimensional ball obtained by projecting A𝐴Aitalic_A orthogonally on an hyperplane with normal v𝑣vitalic_v. Inflatable balls.

A collection ℱℱ\mathcal{F}caligraphic_F of balls in ℝdsuperscriptℝ𝑑\mathbb{R}^{d}blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is called pairwise-inflatable if for every two balls B1,B2∈ℱsubscript𝐵1subscript𝐵2ℱB_{1},B_{2}\in\mathcal{F}italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ caligraphic_F we have γ2>2⁢(r12+r22)superscript𝛾22superscriptsubscript𝑟12superscriptsubscript𝑟22\gamma^{2}>2(r_{1}^{2}+r_{2}^{2})italic_γ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT > 2 ( italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ), where risubscript𝑟𝑖r_{i}italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the radius of Bisubscript𝐵𝑖B_{i}italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ is the distance between their centers. Note that for balls of equal radius, this condition only enforces that they are disjoint (and so any family of disjoint congruent balls is pairwise-inflatable). The more unequal the radius of the balls, however, the stronger the distance constraint. At the limit, when r1=0subscript𝑟10r_{1}=0italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0, the constraint is γ>2⁢r2𝛾2subscript𝑟2\gamma>\sqrt{2}r_{2}italic_γ > square-root start_ARG 2 end_ARG italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Pairwise-inflatability is less restrictive than Hadwiger’s notion of “thinly distributed” balls, which can be defined as γ2>4⁢(r1+r2)2superscript𝛾24superscriptsubscript𝑟1subscript𝑟22\gamma^{2}>4(r_{1}+r_{2})^{2}italic_γ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT > 4 ( italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT for each pair of balls.

The class of families of pairwise-inflatable balls is closed under intersection with affine subspaces (as proved in Lemma 5). This property (which does not hold for unit-radius balls) will allow us to carry results proved in three dimensions over to ℝdsuperscriptℝ𝑑\mathbb{R}^{d}blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

Topological machinery.

We use a few notions from topology that we now review (these can be found, for instance, in the introductory chapter of Matoušek’s book [17]). Given a topological space A𝐴Aitalic_A and a subset B⊂A𝐵𝐴B\subset Aitalic_B ⊂ italic_A, B𝐵Bitalic_B is a deformation retract of A𝐴Aitalic_A if there exists a continuous map F:A×[0,1]→A:𝐹→𝐴01𝐴F:A\times[0,1]\rightarrow Aitalic_F : italic_A × [ 0 , 1 ] → italic_A such that

{F⁢(a,0)=a⁢ for any ⁢a∈AF⁢(b,t)=b⁢ for any b∈B and t∈[0,1]F⁢(a,1)∈B⁢ for any ⁢a∈Acases𝐹𝑎0𝑎 for any 𝑎𝐴𝐹𝑏𝑡𝑏 for any b∈B and t∈[0,1]𝐹𝑎1𝐵 for any 𝑎𝐴\left\{\begin{array}[]{l}F(a,0)=a\hbox{ for any }a\in A\\ F(b,t)=b\hbox{ for any $b\in B$ and $t\in[0,1]$}\\ F(a,1)\in B\hbox{ for any }a\in A\end{array}\right.{ start_ARRAY start_ROW start_CELL italic_F ( italic_a , 0 ) = italic_a for any italic_a ∈ italic_A end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL italic_F ( italic_b , italic_t ) = italic_b for any italic_b ∈ italic_B and italic_t ∈ [ 0 , 1 ] end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL italic_F ( italic_a , 1 ) ∈ italic_B for any italic_a ∈ italic_A end_CELL end_ROW end_ARRAY

Two topological spaces A,B𝐴𝐵A,Bitalic_A , italic_B are homotopy equivalent if there exists a third space C𝐶Citalic_C such that both A𝐴Aitalic_A and B𝐵Bitalic_B are deformation retracts of C𝐶Citalic_C. A space that is homotopy equivalent to a single point is said to be contractible. A homology cell is a non-empty set with trivial homology, e.g. a point. Since homology is invariant under homotopy equivalence, any contractible space is a homology cell. A generalization of Helly’s theorem based on topology instead of convexity was originally given by Helly himself [13]. We will use a version proved by Debrunner using modern tools (singular homology) [6], as it allows us to work with open sets.

Theorem 3 (Topological Helly Theorem [6]).

Let {Xj}j∈Jsubscriptsubscript𝑋𝑗𝑗𝐽\{X_{j}\}_{j\in J}{ italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j ∈ italic_J end_POSTSUBSCRIPT be a finite family of open subsets of Euclidean d𝑑ditalic_d-space ℝdsuperscriptℝ𝑑\mathbb{R}^{d}blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT such that the intersection Xj1∩⋯∩Xjrsubscript𝑋subscript𝑗1normal-⋯subscript𝑋subscript𝑗𝑟X_{j_{1}}\cap\dots\cap X_{j_{r}}italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∩ ⋯ ∩ italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_r end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of each r𝑟ritalic_r sets of this family is nonempty for r⩽d+1𝑟𝑑1r\leqslant d+1italic_r ⩽ italic_d + 1 and is even a homology cell for r⩽d𝑟𝑑r\leqslant ditalic_r ⩽ italic_d. Then ⋂j∈JXjsubscript𝑗𝐽subscript𝑋𝑗\bigcap_{j\in J}X_{j}⋂ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j ∈ italic_J end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is a homology cell.

In fact, we only use a weaker version of this theorem where “homology cell” is replaced by “contractible”.

Compatible directions.

Let 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D}caligraphic_D be a set of directions in ℝdsuperscriptℝ𝑑\mathbb{R}^{d}blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT completely contained in the interior of a hemisphere of 𝕊d−1superscript𝕊𝑑1\mathbb{S}^{d-1}blackboard_S start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, and let ℒ⁢(𝒟)ℒ𝒟\mathcal{L}(\mathcal{D})caligraphic_L ( caligraphic_D ) be the set of lines with directions in 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D}caligraphic_D. We parametrize ℒ⁢(𝒟)ℒ𝒟\mathcal{L}(\mathcal{D})caligraphic_L ( caligraphic_D ) as a subset of ℝ2⁢d−2superscriptℝ2𝑑2\mathbb{R}^{2d-2}blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 italic_d - 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, using the points of intersection of a line ℓ∈ℒ⁢(𝒟)ℓℒ𝒟\ell\in\mathcal{L}(\mathcal{D})roman_ℓ ∈ caligraphic_L ( caligraphic_D ) with two parallel hyperplanes that are not parallel to any direction in 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D}caligraphic_D. Our aim is to apply the Topological Helly Theorem to sets of line transversals to pairwise-inflatable balls. Unfortunately, such sets are not necessarily homology cells, and may in fact even be disconnected: two lines intersecting disjoint objects in different orders cannot be in the same connected component of transversals to these objects. We overcome this difficulty by restricting the set of directions that we allow for transversals. For a sequence ℱℱ\mathcal{F}caligraphic_F of pairwise-inflatable balls in ℝd−1superscriptℝ𝑑1\mathbb{R}^{d-1}blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, let

where c⁢(X)𝑐𝑋c(X)italic_c ( italic_X ) denotes the center of ball X𝑋Xitalic_X. Let 𝒟ℱsubscript𝒟ℱ\mathcal{D}_{\mathcal{F}}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_F end_POSTSUBSCRIPT be the set of directions making a positive dot-product with each u∈U⁢(ℱ)𝑢𝑈ℱu\in U(\mathcal{F})italic_u ∈ italic_U ( caligraphic_F ). Note that 𝒟ℱsubscript𝒟ℱ\mathcal{D}_{\mathcal{F}}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_F end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is an open convex set on the sphere of directions 𝕊d−1superscript𝕊𝑑1\mathbb{S}^{d-1}blackboard_S start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Clearly a line transversal ℓ∈ℒ⁢(𝒟ℱ)ℓℒsubscript𝒟ℱ\ell\in\mathcal{L}(\mathcal{D}_{\mathcal{F}})roman_ℓ ∈ caligraphic_L ( caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_F end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) for a subset ℱ′⊂ℱsuperscriptℱ′ℱ\mathcal{F}^{\prime}\subset\mathcal{F}caligraphic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊂ caligraphic_F respects the order on ℱ′superscriptℱ′\mathcal{F}^{\prime}caligraphic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. 3 The cone of directions is strictly convex

We now establish the cornerstone of this paper, a generalization of the first lemma by Holmsen et al. [14] to arbitrary dimension:

Proposition 4.

Let ℱℱ\mathcal{F}caligraphic_F be a sequence of pairwise-inflatable balls in ℝdsuperscriptℝ𝑑\mathbb{R}^{d}blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Then 𝒦⁢(ℱ)𝒦ℱ\mathcal{K}(\mathcal{F})caligraphic_K ( caligraphic_F ) is strictly convex.

The proof of this proposition is based on Lemma 7, which shows that some well-chosen fibers over 1111-dimensional slices of the cone of directions of unit balls in ℝ4superscriptℝ4\mathbb{R}^{4}blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT are convex. We also need some properties of families of pairwise-inflatable balls. We start by showing that this class is closed under intersection with affine subspaces.

Lemma 7.

If A𝐴Aitalic_A and B𝐵Bitalic_B are disjoint congruent balls in ℝ4superscriptℝ4\mathbb{R}^{4}blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT then QA⁢BFsuperscriptsubscript𝑄𝐴𝐵𝐹Q_{AB}^{F}italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_F end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is convex for any orthogonal frame F𝐹Fitalic_F of ℝ4superscriptℝ4\mathbb{R}^{4}blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

We prove this lemma by showing that QA⁢BFsuperscriptsubscript𝑄𝐴𝐵𝐹Q_{AB}^{F}italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_F end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is the volume under the graph of a concave function of two variables, which involves showing that the Hessian of this function is negative definite. We thus follow the approach of Holmsen et al. [14, proof of Lemma 1] but the details (postponed to Appendix A) are more involved.

We proceed to prove the convexity of 𝒦⁢(ℱ)𝒦ℱ\mathcal{K}(\mathcal{F})caligraphic_K ( caligraphic_F ) (but not yet its strict convexity) for the 3333-dimensional case.

We now characterize the boundary of 𝒦⁢(ℱ)𝒦ℱ\mathcal{K}(\mathcal{F})caligraphic_K ( caligraphic_F ). Lemma 9.

Let ℱℱ\mathcal{F}caligraphic_F be a sequence of disjoint balls in ℝ3superscriptℝ3\mathbb{R}^{3}blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, v∈𝕊2𝑣superscript𝕊2v\in\mathbb{S}^{2}italic_v ∈ blackboard_S start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and D:=⋂Pv⁢(ℱ)assign𝐷subscript𝑃𝑣ℱD:=\bigcap P_{v}(\mathcal{F})italic_D := ⋂ italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_F ). Then v∈∂𝒦⁢(ℱ)𝑣𝒦ℱv\in\partial\mathcal{K}(\mathcal{F})italic_v ∈ ∂ caligraphic_K ( caligraphic_F ) if and only if D𝐷Ditalic_D is a point and v∈int(𝒦⁢(ℱ))𝑣normal-int𝒦ℱv\in\mathop{\operator@font int}\nolimits(\mathcal{K}(\mathcal{F}))italic_v ∈ roman_int ( caligraphic_K ( caligraphic_F ) ) if and only if D𝐷Ditalic_D has non-empty interior.

If D𝐷Ditalic_D has non-empty interior, then a small perturbation of the direction v𝑣vitalic_v cannot cause D𝐷Ditalic_D to become empty, and so v∈int(𝒦⁢(ℱ))𝑣int𝒦ℱv\in\mathop{\operator@font int}\nolimits(\mathcal{K}(\mathcal{F}))italic_v ∈ roman_int ( caligraphic_K ( caligraphic_F ) ). It remains to show that if D𝐷Ditalic_D is a point, then v∈∂𝒦⁢(ℱ)𝑣𝒦ℱv\in\partial\mathcal{K}(\mathcal{F})italic_v ∈ ∂ caligraphic_K ( caligraphic_F ).

We thus assume that D𝐷Ditalic_D is a point. Let k⩾2𝑘2k\geqslant 2italic_k ⩾ 2 be the number of discs that have this point on their boundary, and let ℓℓ\ellroman_ℓ be the (unique) transversal of ℱℱ\mathcal{F}caligraphic_F with direction v𝑣vitalic_v. If k=2𝑘2k=2italic_k = 2 then ℓℓ\ellroman_ℓ lies in a plane separating two balls and there are directions v′superscript𝑣′v^{\prime}italic_v start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT arbitrarily close to v𝑣vitalic_v such that no line transversal with direction v′superscript𝑣′v^{\prime}italic_v start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT to these two balls exists (see Figure 1). Thus, v∈∂𝒦⁢(ℱ)𝑣𝒦ℱv\in\partial\mathcal{K}(\mathcal{F})italic_v ∈ ∂ caligraphic_K ( caligraphic_F ).

If k⩾3𝑘3k\geqslant 3italic_k ⩾ 3 then by Helly’s theorem in the plane there are three balls whose projections intersect in a single point. Let A𝐴Aitalic_A denote the middle one with respect to ≺ℱsubscriptprecedesℱ\prec_{\mathcal{F}}≺ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_F end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and let ℓ′superscriptℓ′\ell^{\prime}roman_ℓ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT be the line through the center of A𝐴Aitalic_A and its tangency point with ℓℓ\ellroman_ℓ (see Figure 2). Consider a rotation of v𝑣vitalic_v by a small angle δ𝛿\deltaitalic_δ around ℓ′superscriptℓ′\ell^{\prime}roman_ℓ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

This rotation leaves Pv⁢(A)subscript𝑃𝑣𝐴P_{v}(A)italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_A ) invariant and moves the centers of the two other projections along lines orthogonal to Pv⁢(ℓ′)subscript𝑃𝑣superscriptℓ′P_{v}(\ell^{\prime})italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( roman_ℓ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ), either both away from Pv⁢(ℓ′)subscript𝑃𝑣superscriptℓ′P_{v}(\ell^{\prime})italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( roman_ℓ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) or both towards Pv⁢(ℓ′)subscript𝑃𝑣superscriptℓ′P_{v}(\ell^{\prime})italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( roman_ℓ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ), depending on the sign of δ𝛿\deltaitalic_δ. In that case we again have v∈∂𝒦⁢(ℱ)𝑣𝒦ℱv\in\partial\mathcal{K}(\mathcal{F})italic_v ∈ ∂ caligraphic_K ( caligraphic_F ). ∎

Lemma 10.

If ℱℱ\mathcal{F}caligraphic_F is a sequence of pairwise inflatable balls in ℝ3superscriptℝ3\mathbb{R}^{3}blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT then 𝒦⁢(ℱ)𝒦ℱ\mathcal{K}(\mathcal{F})caligraphic_K ( caligraphic_F ) is strictly convex.

Proof.

We already know that 𝒦⁢(ℱ)𝒦ℱ\mathcal{K}(\mathcal{F})caligraphic_K ( caligraphic_F ) is convex. If 𝒦⁢(ℱ)𝒦ℱ\mathcal{K}(\mathcal{F})caligraphic_K ( caligraphic_F ) is not strictly convex then it has to contain on its boundary a great circle arc. By the previous lemma, if v∈∂𝒦⁢(ℱ)𝑣𝒦ℱv\in\partial\mathcal{K}(\mathcal{F})italic_v ∈ ∂ caligraphic_K ( caligraphic_F ) then Pv⁢(ℱ)subscript𝑃𝑣ℱP_{v}(\mathcal{F})italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_F ) is a point. This implies, by Helly’s theorem, that the boundary of 𝒦⁢(ℱ)𝒦ℱ\mathcal{K}(\mathcal{F})caligraphic_K ( caligraphic_F ) consists of (finitely many) curve arcs that are either (a) directions of bitangent lines lying in bitangent planes or (b) directions of tritangent lines. The directions of bitangent lines lying in bitangent planes to two balls contain a great circle arc only if the two balls are tangent, which cannot occur in our situation.

Therefore, if 𝒦⁢(ℱ)𝒦ℱ\mathcal{K}(\mathcal{F})caligraphic_K ( caligraphic_F ) is not strictly convex then it contains in its boundary a great circle arc of directions of lines tangent to three balls. These directions, being on a great circle arc, are parallel to a given plane. In projective geometry, parallels to a plane are recast as lines intersecting the “line at infinity” of that plane. Thus, if 𝒦⁢(ℱ)𝒦ℱ\mathcal{K}(\mathcal{F})caligraphic_K ( caligraphic_F ) is not strictly convex, ℱℱ\mathcal{F}caligraphic_F contains three balls with infinitely many common tangents that intersect a fixed line at infinity. Such configurations were tabulated by Megyesi and Sottile [18]. Their cases (i), (iii), and (iv) cannot arise with disjoint spheres and the fixed line at infinity. The remaining possibility (case (ii)) is that the three spheres are tangent to a cone whose apex lies on the fixed line. In our case, that line is at infinity so this cone is a cylinder and the spheres have equal radii and aligned centers; all common tangents then have the same direction and cannot form a great circle arc. ∎

We will need the generalization of Lemma 9 to arbitrary dimension.

Lemma 11.

If ℱℱ\mathcal{F}caligraphic_F is a sequence of disjoint balls in ℝdsuperscriptℝ𝑑\mathbb{R}^{d}blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, then 𝒦∘⁢(ℱ)=int(𝒦⁢(ℱ))superscript𝒦ℱnormal-int𝒦ℱ\mathcal{K}^{\circ}(\mathcal{F})=\mathop{\operator@font int}\nolimits(\mathcal{K}(\mathcal{F}))caligraphic_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∘ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( caligraphic_F ) = roman_int ( caligraphic_K ( caligraphic_F ) ).

Proof.

We can now finally prove the main result of this section.

Proof of Proposition 4.

Proposition 4 has the following important corollary:

Corollary 12.

Let ℱℱ\mathcal{F}caligraphic_F be a sequence of pairwise-inflatable balls in ℝdsuperscriptℝ𝑑\mathbb{R}^{d}blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. If 𝒦⁢(ℱ)𝒦ℱ\mathcal{K}(\mathcal{F})caligraphic_K ( caligraphic_F ) has empty interior then it is a point.

4 Pinning number of pairwise-inflatable balls

A family ℱℱ\mathcal{F}caligraphic_F of objects pins a line ℓℓ\ellroman_ℓ if ℓℓ\ellroman_ℓ is an isolated transversal to ℱℱ\mathcal{F}caligraphic_F. The pinning number of a class 𝒞𝒞\cal Ccaligraphic_C of families of objects is defined as the smallest integer k𝑘kitalic_k such that the following holds: if a family ℱ∈𝒞ℱ𝒞\mathcal{F}\in\cal Ccaligraphic_F ∈ caligraphic_C pins a line ℓℓ\ellroman_ℓ then some subfamily ℱ′⊂ℱsuperscriptℱ′ℱ\mathcal{F}^{\prime}\subset\mathcal{F}caligraphic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊂ caligraphic_F of size at most k𝑘kitalic_k already pins ℓℓ\ellroman_ℓ. A key ingredient in Hadwiger’s original proof of his theorem [12] is the fact that the pinning number of disjoint planar convex sets is 3333. In this section we show a similar result for pairwise-inflatable balls in ℝdsuperscriptℝ𝑑\mathbb{R}^{d}blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Note that the pinning number k𝑘kitalic_k is simply the Helly number for the property of “not being pinned”: if a line transversal to a family ℱℱ\mathcal{F}caligraphic_F is not pinned by any subfamily of size k𝑘kitalic_k then it is not pinned by ℱℱ\mathcal{F}caligraphic_F.

Proposition 13.

The pinning number of pairwise-inflatable balls in ℝdsuperscriptℝ𝑑\mathbb{R}^{d}blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is at most 2⁢d−12𝑑12d-12 italic_d - 1.

Our proof is based on Lemma 14, which shows that sets of compatible transversals are contractible and therefore homology cells, and Lemma 15, which applies the Topological Helly Theorem to these sets of lines and obtains a weak version of our Theorem 1. We state the next lemma using the notion of “compatible” transversal introduced in Section 2:

Lemma 14.

We can now apply the Topological Helly Theorem to obtain a “weak” Hadwiger-type result.

Lemma 15.

Let ℱℱ\mathcal{F}caligraphic_F be a sequence of at least 2⁢d−12𝑑12d-12 italic_d - 1 pairwise-inflatable balls in ℝdsuperscriptℝ𝑑\mathbb{R}^{d}blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Clearly, XSsubscript𝑋𝑆X_{S}italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is an open set in ℝ2⁢d−2superscriptℝ2𝑑2\mathbb{R}^{2d-2}blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 italic_d - 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. In principle, Lemma 15 is the Hadwiger-type result we are looking for. Its drawback is that it requires a subfamily of balls to have not only an order-respecting transversal, but one that, in a sense, respects the order on the entire family of balls. This is nonetheless enough to prove the desired result on the pinning number of pairwise-inflatable balls:

Proof of Proposition 13.

Let ℱℱ\mathcal{F}caligraphic_F be a family of at least 2⁢d2𝑑2d2 italic_d pairwise-inflatable balls in ℝdsuperscriptℝ𝑑\mathbb{R}^{d}blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT admitting an isolated line transversal ℓℓ\ellroman_ℓ. Let ≺precedes\prec≺ be the order on ℱℱ\mathcal{F}caligraphic_F induced by ℓℓ\ellroman_ℓ. Lemma 14 implies that the set of line transversals to ℱℱ\mathcal{F}caligraphic_F respecting ≺precedes\prec≺ is connected, and so ℓℓ\ellroman_ℓ is the only order-respecting line transversal to ℱℱ\mathcal{F}caligraphic_F.

Since ℓℓ\ellroman_ℓ is not a strict transversal, ℱℱ\mathcal{F}caligraphic_F has no strict order-respecting transversal. By Lemma 15, there is a subfamily ℱ′⊂ℱsuperscriptℱ′ℱ\mathcal{F}^{\prime}\subset\mathcal{F}caligraphic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊂ caligraphic_F of 2⁢d−12𝑑12d-12 italic_d - 1 balls that has no strict order-respecting transversal with direction in 𝒟ℱsubscript𝒟ℱ\mathcal{D}_{\mathcal{F}}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_F end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, that is 𝒦∘⁢(ℱ′)∩𝒟ℱ=∅superscript𝒦superscriptℱ′subscript𝒟ℱ\mathcal{K}^{\circ}(\mathcal{F}^{\prime})\cap\mathcal{D}_{\mathcal{F}}=\emptysetcaligraphic_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∘ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( caligraphic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ∩ caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_F end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ∅. However, 𝒦⁢(ℱ′)∩𝒟ℱ≠∅𝒦superscriptℱ′subscript𝒟ℱ\mathcal{K}(\mathcal{F}^{\prime})\cap\mathcal{D}_{\mathcal{F}}\neq\emptysetcaligraphic_K ( caligraphic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ∩ caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_F end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≠ ∅ since it contains the direction of ℓℓ\ellroman_ℓ. Since 𝒦⁢(ℱ′)𝒦superscriptℱ′\mathcal{K}(\mathcal{F}^{\prime})caligraphic_K ( caligraphic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) is convex, by Lemma 4, and 𝒟ℱsubscript𝒟ℱ\mathcal{D}_{\mathcal{F}}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_F end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is open, it follows that 𝒦∘⁢(ℱ′)=∅superscript𝒦superscriptℱ′\mathcal{K}^{\circ}(\mathcal{F}^{\prime})=\emptysetcaligraphic_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∘ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( caligraphic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = ∅ and ℱ′superscriptℱ′\mathcal{F}^{\prime}caligraphic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT has no strict order-respecting transversal at all. Now, 𝒦⁢(ℱ′)𝒦superscriptℱ′\mathcal{K}(\mathcal{F}^{\prime})caligraphic_K ( caligraphic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) is non-empty but has empty interior, so, by Corollary 12, 𝒦⁢(ℱ′)𝒦superscriptℱ′\mathcal{K}(\mathcal{F}^{\prime})caligraphic_K ( caligraphic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) is a single direction v𝑣vitalic_v. Since 𝒦⁢(ℱ′)={v}𝒦superscriptℱ′𝑣\mathcal{K}(\mathcal{F}^{\prime})=\{v\}caligraphic_K ( caligraphic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = { italic_v }, the balls Pv⁢(ℱ′)subscript𝑃𝑣superscriptℱ′P_{v}(\mathcal{F}^{\prime})italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) intersect in a unique point and ℓℓ\ellroman_ℓ is the only order-respecting line transversal of ℱ′superscriptℱ′\mathcal{F}^{\prime}caligraphic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, and is thus isolated. ∎

5 Hadwiger and Helly-type theorems

We can now prove the main results of this paper.

A Hadwiger-type theorem.

Propositions 12 and 13 are all we need to reproduce Hadwiger’s original proof of the 2222-dimensional case.

Proof of Theorem 1.

We simultaneously shrink all the balls and continue shrinking as long as every subset of size 2⁢d2𝑑2d2 italic_d has a transversal. If all the centers are aligned then the theorem trivially holds. Otherwise, at some point in the shrinking process a subfamily ℱ′superscriptℱ′\mathcal{F}^{\prime}caligraphic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT of size 2⁢d2𝑑2d2 italic_d stops having a transversal. The cone 𝒦⁢(ℱ′)𝒦superscriptℱ′\mathcal{K}(\mathcal{F}^{\prime})caligraphic_K ( caligraphic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) changes continuously during the shrinking and must have empty interior before disappearing. Thus, by Corollary 12, at that moment the sequence ℱ′superscriptℱ′\mathcal{F}^{\prime}caligraphic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT has a unique transversal ℓℓ\ellroman_ℓ.

Now, by Proposition 13, there is then a subfamily ℱ′′⊂ℱ′superscriptℱ′′superscriptℱ′\mathcal{F}^{\prime\prime}\subset\mathcal{F}^{\prime}caligraphic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊂ caligraphic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT of at most 2⁢d−12𝑑12d-12 italic_d - 1 balls such that ℓℓ\ellroman_ℓ is the unique transversal of ℱ′′superscriptℱ′′\mathcal{F}^{\prime\prime}caligraphic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. For any ball X∈ℱ∖ℱ′′𝑋ℱsuperscriptℱ′′X\in\mathcal{F}\setminus\mathcal{F}^{\prime\prime}italic_X ∈ caligraphic_F ∖ caligraphic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, the set ℱ′′∪{X}superscriptℱ′′𝑋\mathcal{F}^{\prime\prime}\cup\{X\}caligraphic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∪ { italic_X } has a line transversal ℓXsubscriptℓ𝑋\ell_{X}roman_ℓ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_X end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Since the only line transversal of ℱ′′superscriptℱ′′\mathcal{F}^{\prime\prime}caligraphic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is ℓℓ\ellroman_ℓ, we must have ℓX=ℓsubscriptℓ𝑋ℓ\ell_{X}=\ellroman_ℓ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_X end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = roman_ℓ, and ℓℓ\ellroman_ℓ intersects X𝑋Xitalic_X. It follows that ℓℓ\ellroman_ℓ is an unordered line transversal for ℱℱ\mathcal{F}caligraphic_F.

Similarly, if any subfamily of size 2⁢d+12𝑑12d+12 italic_d + 1 admits a line transversal there exists a subfamily ℱ′superscriptℱ′\mathcal{F}^{\prime}caligraphic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT of 2⁢d−12𝑑12d-12 italic_d - 1 balls having a unique line transversal ℓℓ\ellroman_ℓ. For any X,Y∈ℱ𝑋𝑌ℱX,Y\in\mathcal{F}italic_X , italic_Y ∈ caligraphic_F with X≺Yprecedes𝑋𝑌X\prec Yitalic_X ≺ italic_Y, the subfamily ℱ′∪{X,Y}superscriptℱ′𝑋𝑌\mathcal{F}^{\prime}\cup\{X,Y\}caligraphic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∪ { italic_X , italic_Y } admits a line transversal that must be ℓℓ\ellroman_ℓ, and ℓℓ\ellroman_ℓ intersects X𝑋Xitalic_X before Y𝑌Yitalic_Y. It follows that ℓℓ\ellroman_ℓ is an (order-respecting) line transversal of ℱℱ\mathcal{F}caligraphic_F. ∎

Removing the ordering assumption.

We now generalize Theorem 1 by removing the restriction on the ordering. However, we restrict ourselves to the case of disjoint unit balls in ℝdsuperscriptℝ𝑑\mathbb{R}^{d}blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT as we build on the following result by Cheong et al. [4].

Theorem 16 ([4]).

Let ℱℱ\mathcal{F}caligraphic_F be a family of at least nine disjoint unit balls in ℝdsuperscriptℝ𝑑\mathbb{R}^{d}blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Then ℱℱ\mathcal{F}caligraphic_F admits at most two distinct geometric permutations, which differ only in the swapping of two adjacent balls.

Proof of Theorem 2.

We first shrink the balls simultaneously until some subfamily ℱ4⁢d−1subscriptℱ4𝑑1\mathcal{F}_{4d-1}caligraphic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 4 italic_d - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of 4⁢d−14𝑑14d-14 italic_d - 1 balls is about to lose its last unordered transversal.

If ℱ4⁢d−1subscriptℱ4𝑑1\mathcal{F}_{4d-1}caligraphic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 4 italic_d - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT admits more than one (unordered) line transversal (all of which vanish if the balls are shrunk any further), each transversal must realize a different geometric permutation. Theorem 16 then implies that ℱ4⁢d−1subscriptℱ4𝑑1\mathcal{F}_{4d-1}caligraphic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 4 italic_d - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT has exactly two line transversals, ℓ1subscriptℓ1\ell_{1}roman_ℓ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and ℓ2subscriptℓ2\ell_{2}roman_ℓ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, with two distinct geometric permutations. By Proposition 13, for each ℓisubscriptℓ𝑖\ell_{i}roman_ℓ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT there are 2⁢d−12𝑑12d-12 italic_d - 1 balls in ℱ4⁢d−1subscriptℱ4𝑑1\mathcal{F}_{4d-1}caligraphic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 4 italic_d - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for which ℓisubscriptℓ𝑖\ell_{i}roman_ℓ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the only line transversal respecting the ordering induced by ℓisubscriptℓ𝑖\ell_{i}roman_ℓ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. By Theorem 16, ℱ′superscriptℱ′\mathcal{F}^{\prime}caligraphic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT admits at most two geometric permutations, and so ℓ1subscriptℓ1\ell_{1}roman_ℓ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and ℓ2subscriptℓ2\ell_{2}roman_ℓ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are its only line transversals. Since any subfamily of 4⁢d−14𝑑14d-14 italic_d - 1 balls has a line transversal, any ball of ℱ∖ℱ′ℱsuperscriptℱ′\mathcal{F}\setminus\mathcal{F}^{\prime}caligraphic_F ∖ caligraphic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT must intersect ℓ1subscriptℓ1\ell_{1}roman_ℓ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT or ℓ2subscriptℓ2\ell_{2}roman_ℓ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. If all the balls intersect both lines then the theorem is proved. Otherwise, there exists a ball A𝐴Aitalic_A that intersects, say, ℓ1subscriptℓ1\ell_{1}roman_ℓ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT but not ℓ2subscriptℓ2\ell_{2}roman_ℓ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Then ℱ′∪{A}superscriptℱ′𝐴\mathcal{F}^{\prime}\cup\{A\}caligraphic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∪ { italic_A } is a family of 4⁢d−14𝑑14d-14 italic_d - 1 balls with a unique transversal. We are left with a set ℱ4⁢d−1subscriptℱ4𝑑1\mathcal{F}_{4d-1}caligraphic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 4 italic_d - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of 4⁢d−14𝑑14d-14 italic_d - 1 balls that has a unique transversal ℓℓ\ellroman_ℓ.

Let ≺ℓsubscriptprecedesℓ\prec_{\ell}≺ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ℓ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT be the order on ℱ4⁢d−1subscriptℱ4𝑑1\mathcal{F}_{4d-1}caligraphic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 4 italic_d - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT induced by ℓℓ\ellroman_ℓ. By Proposition 13, there is a subfamily ℱ2⁢d−1⊂ℱ4⁢d−1subscriptℱ2𝑑1subscriptℱ4𝑑1\mathcal{F}_{2d-1}\subset\mathcal{F}_{4d-1}caligraphic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 italic_d - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⊂ caligraphic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 4 italic_d - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT such that ℓℓ\ellroman_ℓ is the unique transversal of ℱ2⁢d−1subscriptℱ2𝑑1\mathcal{F}_{2d-1}caligraphic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 italic_d - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT respecting ≺ℓsubscriptprecedesℓ\prec_{\ell}≺ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ℓ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. For each Z∈ℱ4⁢d−1∖ℱ2⁢d−1𝑍subscriptℱ4𝑑1subscriptℱ2𝑑1Z\in\mathcal{F}_{4d-1}\setminus\mathcal{F}_{2d-1}italic_Z ∈ caligraphic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 4 italic_d - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∖ caligraphic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 italic_d - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, let ℱZsubscriptℱ𝑍\mathcal{F}_{Z}caligraphic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT denote the set ℱ4⁢d−1∖{Z}subscriptℱ4𝑑1𝑍\mathcal{F}_{4d-1}\setminus\{Z\}caligraphic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 4 italic_d - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∖ { italic_Z }. Let Z1,Z2∈ℱ4⁢d−1∖ℱ2⁢d−1subscript𝑍1subscript𝑍2subscriptℱ4𝑑1subscriptℱ2𝑑1Z_{1},Z_{2}\in\mathcal{F}_{4d-1}\setminus\mathcal{F}_{2d-1}italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ caligraphic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 4 italic_d - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∖ caligraphic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 italic_d - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and consider the set ℱ4⁢d−1∖{Z1,Z2}subscriptℱ4𝑑1subscript𝑍1subscript𝑍2\mathcal{F}_{4d-1}\setminus\{Z_{1},Z_{2}\}caligraphic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 4 italic_d - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∖ { italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT }. By (the second half of) Theorem 1, there is a subset ℱ2⁢d+1⊂ℱ4⁢d−1subscriptℱ2𝑑1subscriptℱ4𝑑1\mathcal{F}_{2d+1}\subset\mathcal{F}_{4d-1}caligraphic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 italic_d + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⊂ caligraphic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 4 italic_d - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of at most 2⁢d+12𝑑12d+12 italic_d + 1 balls that does not admit a transversal respecting ≺precedes\prec≺. This implies that |ℱ2⁢d−1∪ℱ2⁢d+1|⩽4⁢d−2subscriptℱ2𝑑1subscriptℱ2𝑑14𝑑2|\mathcal{F}_{2d-1}\cup\mathcal{F}_{2d+1}|\leqslant 4d-2| caligraphic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 italic_d - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∪ caligraphic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 italic_d + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | ⩽ 4 italic_d - 2. However, ℓZsubscriptℓ𝑍\ell_{Z}roman_ℓ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT cannot be a line transversal to ℱ2⁢d+1subscriptℱ2𝑑1\mathcal{F}_{2d+1}caligraphic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 italic_d + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, a contradiction. ∎

6 Conclusion and open problems

We conclude this paper with a few comments on our results followed by open problems they suggest.

  • •

    Weaker versions of Theorems 1 and 2 (with constants quadratic in d𝑑ditalic_d) can be obtained more easily, using only Lemma 4 and the reasoning of Holmsen et al. [14].

  • •

    In the plane, if three disjoint convex sets {C1,…,C3}subscript𝐶1…subscript𝐶3\{C_{1},\ldots,C_{3}\}{ italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } pin a line ℓℓ\ellroman_ℓ then they are all tangent to ℓℓ\ellroman_ℓ and alternate: the first and the third are on the same side of ℓℓ\ellroman_ℓ, the second is on the other side. Thus, if ℓℓ\ellroman_ℓ does not intersect a fourth convex set C4subscript𝐶4C_{4}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT some triple {Cx,Cy,C4}subscript𝐶𝑥subscript𝐶𝑦subscript𝐶4\{C_{x},C_{y},C_{4}\}{ italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } has no line transversal at all. This explains why, in Hadwiger’s original proof the “Hadwiger number” is the same as the pinning number. A way to reduce the bound in Theorem 1 to 2⁢d−12𝑑12d-12 italic_d - 1 could be to prove a similar statement: given a sequence of pairwise inflatable balls ℱℱ\mathcal{F}caligraphic_F that pins a line ℓℓ\ellroman_ℓ and a ball C𝐶Citalic_C not intersecting ℓℓ\ellroman_ℓ, there is a subsequence ℱ′⊂ℱsuperscriptℱ′ℱ\mathcal{F}^{\prime}\subset\mathcal{F}caligraphic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊂ caligraphic_F of size |ℱ|−1ℱ1|\mathcal{F}|-1| caligraphic_F | - 1 such that ℱ′∪{C}superscriptℱ′𝐶\mathcal{F}^{\prime}\cup\{C\}caligraphic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∪ { italic_C } has no transversal respecting the ordering on ℱ′superscriptℱ′\mathcal{F}^{\prime}caligraphic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. We have no idea whether such a statement actually holds.

  • •

    To apply the Topological Helly Theorem, we did not actually need that 𝒦⁢(ℱ)𝒦ℱ\mathcal{K}(\mathcal{F})caligraphic_K ( caligraphic_F ) is convex, only that it is contractible. This may be important for further generalization.

  • •

    For general convex sets, even smooth ones, the pinning number is at least 6666 as the following example using six unit-radius cylinders in ℝ3superscriptℝ3\mathbb{R}^{3}blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, due to Günter Rote, shows: the first three cylinders are parallel to the x𝑥xitalic_x-axis and their axes go through the points (0,1,0)010(0,1,0)( 0 , 1 , 0 ), (0,−1,1)011(0,-1,1)( 0 , - 1 , 1 ) and (0,1,2)012(0,1,2)( 0 , 1 , 2 ) respectively. The last three cylinders are parallel to the y𝑦yitalic_y-axis and their axes go through the points (1,0,10)1010(1,0,10)( 1 , 0 , 10 ), (−1,0,11)1011(-1,0,11)( - 1 , 0 , 11 ) and (1,0,12)1012(1,0,12)( 1 , 0 , 12 ) respectively. The six cylinders have only one transversal—the z𝑧zitalic_z-axis—but any five have an infinite number of transversals.

  • •

    Lemmas 5 and 6 imply that two disjoint balls A,B⊂ℝd𝐴𝐵superscriptℝ𝑑A,B\subset\mathbb{R}^{d}italic_A , italic_B ⊂ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT are pairwise-inflatable if and only if they can be expressed as sections of two disjoint congruent balls in some higher-dimensional space. Generalizing this, let us call a set ℱℱ\mathcal{F}caligraphic_F of balls in ℝdsuperscriptℝ𝑑\mathbb{R}^{d}blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT inflatable if ℱℱ\mathcal{F}caligraphic_F can be expressed as the intersection of a higher-dimensional set of disjoint congruent balls with a d𝑑ditalic_d-dimensional affine subspace. Batog recently showed that it is NP-hard to decide whether a given collection of balls is inflatable [2].


Problem 1.

What is the maximum number of geometric permutations of pairwise-inflatable balls in ℝdsuperscriptℝ𝑑\mathbb{R}^{d}blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT?

To generalize Theorem 2 to pairwise-inflatable balls, one would need to extend Theorem 16 to those families. It is known that the number of geometric permutations of n𝑛nitalic_n disjoint balls in ℝdsuperscriptℝ𝑑\mathbb{R}^{d}blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is at most 3333 if the balls have equal radii and Θ⁢(nd−1)Θsuperscript𝑛𝑑1\Theta(n^{d-1})roman_Θ ( italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) if the ratio

largest radiussmallest radiuslargest radiussmallest radius\frac{\hbox{largest radius}}{\hbox{smallest radius}}divide start_ARG largest radius end_ARG start_ARG smallest radius end_ARG

is not bounded independently of n𝑛nitalic_n [21].

Problem 2.

For which classes of objects is the cone of directions 𝒦⁢(A1,…,An)𝒦subscript𝐴1normal-…subscript𝐴𝑛\mathcal{K}(A_{1},\ldots,A_{n})caligraphic_K ( italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) convex, or at least contractible?

Our proof of convexity for the cone of directions of balls collapses for balls that are not pairwise-inflatable. In fact, the set QA⁢BFsuperscriptsubscript𝑄𝐴𝐵𝐹Q_{AB}^{F}italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_F end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is not necessarily convex if B𝐵Bitalic_B is much smaller than A𝐴Aitalic_A but very close to it.

Problem 3.

For which classes of objects is the set of order-respecting line transversals always connected?

Our proof of Theorem 1 follows from (i) a bounded pinning number and (ii) the fact that as the set of order-respecting line transversals to a sequence disappears it first reduces to a single line. For strictly convex objects, property (ii) follows from the connectivity of the set of order-respecting transversals. Surprisingly, it is an open question whether this set is connected for even 4444 disjoint balls in ℝ3superscriptℝ3\mathbb{R}^{3}blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, whereas it is known to be connected for any triple of disjoint convex objects [7, Lemma 74]. We conjecture that general convex sets in ℝdsuperscriptℝ𝑑\mathbb{R}^{d}blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT have a bounded pinning number. Thus, understanding how general this connectivity property is would provide insight in how general the example of Holmsen and Matousek [15], convex sets whose translates do not admit a Hadwiger theorem, actually is. Of course, a positive answer to Problem 2 for a particular family of convex sets implies a positive answer to Problem 3 for that family as well.

Problem 4.

Given a collection of disjoint unit balls, assume that any subset of size 2⁢d−12𝑑12d-12 italic_d - 1 admits a line transversal. Does any subset of size 2⁢d−12𝑑12d-12 italic_d - 1 admit a compatible line transversal?

In other words, can our “weak Hadwiger theorem” (Lemma 15) be strengthened into a Hadwiger theorem with a better constant than Theorem 1?

Problem 5.

Is the pinning number of disjoint unit balls in ℝdsuperscriptℝ𝑑\mathbb{R}^{d}blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT equal to 2⁢d−12𝑑12d-12 italic_d - 1?

Surprisingly, the only known lower bound on the Helly number is the construction done by Hadwiger fifty years ago. Note that the bound in our Hadwiger theorem has to be higher than the pinning number of the corresponding family and one can therefore look for a lower bound on the pinning number. Intuitively, considerations on the dimension suggest that the pinning number in dimension d𝑑ditalic_d cannot be less than 2⁢d−12𝑑12d-12 italic_d - 1, the dimension of the underlying line space being 2⁢d−22𝑑22d-22 italic_d - 2.
